reviewText:
Pros:
- excellent art, both for backgrounds and characters
- quirky characters and NPCs
- intriguing story that can be very unpredictable
- on-point humor when you do and don't expect it
- you can romance select people in your party
- many throwbacks and references to previous games and characters in the Aveyond series
- simple controls
- militant squirrels
- combat is intuitive but can be challenging if you don't know what to expect

Cons:
- you do have to grind on occasion (unless you're on the easiest setting)
- there is a version of fast travel, but it still takes a significant chunk time to get from place to place
- some sidequests are unnecessarily convoluted (but only a few)
- doesn't appear to have much replay value
- bears
- Te'ijal's sprite still doesn't match her appearance

I originally bought this from Amaranth's website when it first came out and I received a free Steam key as a result. I haven't yet completed the game, but it's definitely worth the money - especially if you've played previous games from the Aveyond series!

reviewText:
I am a full-on Aveyond Kingdom fan. Amaranth/Aveyond Kingdom and John Wizard are my 2 favorite game makers, and they frequently collaborate with each other. Their games are reminiscent of the old Square Soft games, for the Super Nintendo with strong stories and fun sidequests. They are as much fun as The Legend of Zelda or any early Final Fantasy game ever was.

Aveyond Kingdom’s Aveyond 4, Shadow of the Mist is in many ways, a more polished production than their earlier work.  The graphics and backgrounds are the best they have produced by far. The storyline is both deep and hilarious, and the characters are, for the most part, engaging.

This game incorporates the traditional elements of puzzle-solving, action, and adventure into a neat and enjoyable package. There are the usual elements of high fantasy, with the characters ruthlessly poking fun at themselves. The enemies are creative and fun to fight.

Because they are failed villains, Boyle and Ingrid are unhappily in love, and that storyline adds ongoing humorous elements. Myst and Robin are naive and make good foils for Boyle and Ingrid. Hi’beru and Rowen arrive later in the game, and Phye arrives so late I did wonder why he was included at all. As a Draghar, Phye does have some power, but I think like a writer, so in my opinion, all the characters should be in place at the midpoint. Because he arrives so close to the end, we don’t get to know him as well as I would have liked.

I purchased the game the day it was released. I have played the game through to the end four times. The first time through, I had Ingrid join Lorelei’s coven and married her off to Boyle. With that scenario the game played smoothly with no glitches. I was in love with the game!

The second time through I had Ingrid join Jinx’s coven, but when I tried to complete the task of selling the craft in Robin’s store, the game froze and I had to take drastic measures to close the game down. No matter what I did, in this scenario the game froze at that point every time.

So I went to their website and, following the suggestions in their forums, I reinstalled the game. I never got past that point on that particular attempt.

So I started a new game, and that time I had her join the transformations coven. This went well for the most part, but with one major flaw. Ingrid gained the ability to transform into a dragon, but the skill didn’t appear in her menu. When I went out to the forums to see how to solve that, the answer was that it would be resolved in the next build. I was disappointed, as I did want to have the ability to play her as a dragon.

However, that time I married Ingrid off to Hi’beru, which was cute.

The environments that the game is set in are lush and beautiful, dark and moody. The music is amazing and really contributes to the enjoyment of the game.

The game is fun, hilarious, and when it works properly, it’s a great way to spend 25 or so hours.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my low play time; I bought it from their website originally and just got the key. This is my first ever review, too! Mostly because I'm super lazy. Now here you go: 10/10

This is a great game. I've been a follower of the Aveyond series since it first came out years ago, and (unlike many series), the quality has only gone up with each game.

Story and writing: The story is amazing. Aveyond is what got me into RPGs in the first place, and I've yet to come across another that has such well-written characters and a cohesive plot. It's made me laugh from the get-go and has a bit of a different spin from the other games; this time, you're playing from the perspective of a retired villian who's sort of forced into the role of hero. It's original and well-done, without gramatical or spelling errors.

Music: The soundtrack is, as always, incredible. Aaron Walz has really outdone himself with this one.

Gameplay and controls: There are both keyboard and mouse functions, for whichever you prefer, and everything is really easy to figure out without being annoying. It's pretty stnadard, but in a good way.

Art: Aveyond has given me extemely high standards for art, and is the sole reason why I'm hesitant to play many other RPGs that aren't quite up to par. SotM very much keeps with this standard. The art is beautiful and expressive, and unlike many other games that have decent art to provide nothing more than a visual, the art in this game really adds something. The expressions are hilarious and personal, and you can really tell that a lot of effort was put in.

Combat: Simple without being boring. It's turn-based and the abilities of each character are truly well thought-out.

My impression as a whole: Play the damn game. It's very much worth the price (and to be honest, one of the only games that I'm willing to spend more than $10 on), and the more people who play, the easier it is for the series to continue on and flourish. If you're new to the series, absolutely give it a shot. Hell, give all of them a shot. They're all great. If you're a veteran, well, you probably already own it. 10/10

reviewText:
A truly enjoyable RPG!  Just plain fun.

From the makers of the Aveyond series (all wonderfully made), this is a departure from the original storyline. It is a complete, stand alone game, although there are some subtle references to the previous games, they are there to give you a chuckle, but in no way impact the story.

You play Boyle, a villain, who becomes, through many misadventures, an unwilling hero. The characters are all unique, with unique skills/attributes/mannerisms. While the main story is very linear, there are TONS of side quests to pursue. Some are mentioned in your log book. Some you will stumble upon, and need to remember.

The battle system is great, turn based, and each character has very different skills to work with. The artwork is a pleasure to look at. But I think where this game shines is just the sheer funness". The writing was just hilarious in so many parts. It's like being part of a group of people that are thrown together

reviewText:
Once in a great while you find a series of games that become milemarkers through the changes and phases of your life.  When I first began playing Ahriman's Prophecy, my daughter was just beginning high school.  I was excited, as our new computer had a brand new operating system called Windows XP.

Fastforward to last summer.  My granddaughter came to stay with my husband and I for the summer.  She played through Aveyond, Aveyond 2 and the various chapters of Aveyond 3.  She quickly fell in love with the games, as had her mother and I years before.  When I told her that the release of Aveyond 4 was on the horizon, she became at least as excited as many fans of the Fallout series, awaiting Fallout 4.

Aveyond is a familiar place, and has seen at least as many changes as the lives of the wonderful people who make up the fanbase. If you're looking for an intense, fast paced game with gore and violence aplenty, move along.  If you'd like to recover some of the innocent wonder and happiness the world so callously tries to strip away, welcome to The Kingdom. Relax, sit back and just...play.

If you've ever had a beloved pet go missing, you'll know very well the depths of despair and challenges of finding them  and bringing them safely home again. In Aveyond 4 you'll revisit this issue, but with a wonderful twist.  There are riddles to be solved, mountains to climb, tournaments to win, and a narcissistic king who simply will not take no for an answer.   Aveyond 4 is packed with various  quests.  There are old friends, new heroes, dragons, elves and wicked witches. Have you ever pondered the meaning of a particularly disturbing nightmare?  Someone in this game might have the answer. Love, betrayal and wonder await you.

If you've ever enjoyed wandering around town and country with a good friend while the rest of the world is quietly slumbering, aiding a hilarious faction that desires to rule the world (a top secret faction that might actually do a better job than the figurehead in place), give this game a try!

This game is not a race, it's a meandering walk throught he woods, exploring every leaf, feeling the wind in your hair and the warmth of the summer sun on your face.  Slow down, lock your inner critic in the dungeon buy this game and just enjoy.

I purchased this game from the Aveyond website a few months back.  When I heard that Aveyond 4 was coming out on Steam, I wrote to ask of I could review the game here.  The deleloper was kind enough to send me a key code for downloading the game here on Steam.  I delighted for the opportunity to review it.  Give Aveyond 4 a try.

reviewText:
Aveyond 4  gave me a nice break from Skyrim.   The entire Aveyond series are among my favorite games, right up there with Skyrim, Fable 3, Fable 2, King's Quest and Dawn's Light.   I got this game through Amaranth games first and received a free steam key to review the game here on Steam.

Aveyond 4, so far my favorite of the series, has an excellent storyline that pulls you right in from the start and keeps your interests with plot twists, entertaining characters and npc's.   Some highlights -- militant squirrels, plenty of humor sometimes when you least expect it, simple controls, beautiful artwork, both the characters and the backgrounds.  And the loot, including hidden goodie caves filled with treasure.

I recommend playing the entire Aveyond series.

reviewText:
I am so happy to see Aveyond come on to Steam.  The entire series should be on Steam. Aveyond 4 is the newest release in this wonderful series. The first was in 2006- I have been following it for the last 10 years. This is one of the most clever and unique RPG games you will find.  It is intensely story-driven, immersive, and extremely well-written.  The graphics, while not your typical Skyrim-ish style, are beautiful and engaging. Oh, and the music!! I believe Aaron Walz does the music, and it is just so lovely. I have kept the games on just to play the music for ambience.

Aveyond 4 is about Boyle and his friends- he is a failed villain on a new quest with  some new friends.  It's a funny game.  Very witty. And you get to shapeshift and catch cheekis. And minions!  You can have minions!

DISCLAIMER: I did receive a Steam code for the came in exchange for this review, HOWEVER I did purchase the game from the developer the day it came out, and i would have written the review anyhow. A lot of heart went into this game and the entire series.

reviewText:
I have long been a fan of the Aveyond games.  However, you do *not* need to have played any of the others to enjoy or understand this game.  There are a couple of long-lived recurring non-playable minor characters from earlier series, but they do not play major roles in this game.  This is also a complete game, unlike the 4-part Aveyond 3.

You can play this with either a keyboard or a mouse.  I generally prefer the keyboard unless I am trying to navigate tricky terrain or avoid a bad guy without a fight.

This is a long, detailed, well-imagined fantasy game.  There are battles, and you can have up to four fighters (plus one minion) from amongst your seven party members (you won't have seven party members the whole game, for most of it you will have fewer than seven).  Each character has different battle skills and strengths, and you may not want the same fighters in every situation.  You will have a chance to experience the battle interface during the demo.

The party does not always remain the same, either.  Although Boyle is the main character, occasionally other playable characters will have quests without him.   All the characters have unique backgrounds, and many are very different characters than we have seen in previous games.

There is a lot of fun, snarky humor in this game, especially with two of the MCs (Boyle and Ingrid) being an ex-villain and a witch.  Possibly reformed characters make great reluctant heroes.   Boyle's primary loyalty is to his dog/wolf Fang.  It takes him a while to get used to being part of a group.

I don't want to give away much of the plot, but there many different locations in this expansive world, allowing for many different creatures and scenery.  (Mountains, forest, farmland, desert, seaside mining town, swamp, dreamscape, etc).  There are a bunch of main quests, and a fair number of optional side-quests with useful rewards.

There are several options for replayability, too, especially involving Ingrid, who can marry one of several men, depending on who she fancies and how much work she puts into it, and also join one of three witches covens, each with its own unique spells.  Eventually I want to try al the options.

So, try the demo and see if this is the sort of game you like.  (Note: the first half-hour is more scripted than the rest of the game, so do not be misled or turned off by the initial nudging).

Also, my tip to you - save early and often, especially before battle.  And talk to everyone you encounter.

I had (and am having) lots of fun with this game and I hope you do too.  In some respects it is like immersing yourself in an interactive book/movie and experiencing a deep and nuanced world.  You might have to put more effort into it that the normal shooter or point-and-click games, but you will be rewarded for your efforts with a unique experience most games do not give you.  Most games are forgettable and interchangeable, but I always remember the Aveyond games and characters long after I am done playing.  Aveyond 4 makes me smile and forget about the real world for a while.

Disclaimer: I bought the PC version of this game when it was first released in December, and received a free Steam key from the developer.

reviewText:
I bought this game direct from Amaranth Games when it first came out and received a free Steam key for feedback.

I have enjoyed all of the Aveyond games, but this may be my favorite.  The characters are well developed and the humor is great.

Battles are challenging without being a chore, but certain enemies are tough even on the easy setting.  I found very little grinding to be necessary on the normal setting - usually just needing to switch my party around to suit certain enemies.  Every character is useful at some point.

There are plenty of sidequests with great rewards and some puzzles that are fun to work through.  I have played completely through the game three times to try all possible covens and get all the different marriages at the end.

The main con with the game is that there is a lag in certain areas.  Shutting down background programs helps a little, but doesn't really fix it.  Another minor issue is that you have to buy items one at a time which is a bit of a pain when trying to stock up before a boss battle.

While the game does have references to the previous games in the series, it is not necessary to play them first and this game can stand very well on its own.

reviewText:
I would highly recommend AV4: Shadow Of The Mist to anyone who loves RPG games.
I bought this game initially when it was released on the developers website and I recieved a free key for the Steam release of the game.

The game is funny engaging and a really good play, with three modes of play, I played the easy mode on my first play through, currently on Steam I'm playing on normal, and I'll finally play hard mode.

The story is a little differnt from the normal hero tale, how can it not be when the hero is a retired villian and interaction between party members makes it much more alive, some of the dialogue had me laughing out loud.

It also ties into other AV games with more than a nod to past related topics, squirels and sword singers to name a couple.

Lots of puzzles to solve a great touch, a new and old characters to meet and fall in love with.

And does the ending hint at a new AV game may be on the cards, we can but hope

A game that is suitable for both experienced and new rpg fans

reviewText:
Although it looks like I haven't played much of this game, in reality I have beat it! I received a free copy of this game on Steam after purchasing it from another source in return for writing this review. In my game, I've played around 40 hours, and it was all an absolute delight!

Aveyond has been a series I have been playing since I was a little girl, and I've always eagerly awaited all the additions to the series. By far, Aveyond 4 has been my favourite contribution. Although it says Aveyond '4', don't let that fool you! This game is very much a standalone game. It's set in the same universe as the previous Aveyond games, but other than a few teeny tiny references that don't matter much to actual gamepla
y, you don't need to play previous games! Still, I think this game would be an amazing beginning to an Aveyond journey, and I sincerely hope anyone who purchases this game goes back and plays the past games. <3

This game is in a style I adore, and the plot is fantastically witty, along with dialogue that can compare to some of the most popular games on the market. It's so damn funny! Buy this game people! You won't have any regrets!

reviewText: I have played Aveyond since I was seven, in 2006. I watched my mom play the first. My brother and I would help my mom by trying to figure out hard places. I loved it, and by the time the second game was released, my mom let us play it. I love role playing games, and these are my favorite. I loved playing the previous games. This game started out great! I am not going to spoil anything, but let's just say there has been a really cool change in the series, and when you play, you will figure it out! Amaranth Games, you have blown me away since I was seven, and you will continue to do so in the future! Thank you so much for creating a really cool and funny bond between me, my brother, and our mother!

reviewText: This game is very amusing, mainly due to the writing.  The anti-hero turned hero is a great premise.  The best feature is the click pathfinding.  It can sometimes relieve you of manually walking around a large obstacle like a tree to get to a place you can see on the screen.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
20 hours in and I've finished my first playthrough.  I loved this game!  I'm a big fan of the whole Aveyond series.  This one ties in nicely to the other games, but you can definitely play it without having played the others - there's just little bonus jokes and such that you only get if you've played all the games.  The dialog is funny, clever, cute and well-written.  All the grammar and spelling is correct (one of my pet peeves is games with incorrect grammar and spelling, the Aveyond ones are safe from that).
This is an RPG Maker game with very cute sprites.  The sprites are very nice, and you can actually tell which sprite is which character.  The art (the non-RPG maker generated art) is lovely; the character art in particular was great, with very expressive faces (that actually looked like realistic emotions instead of something out of a Looney Toon).

I recommend this to anyone with a good sense of humor, and anyone who likes RPGs.  If you liked the other Aveyond games, you'll almost certainly enjoy this.  If you liked Cthulhu Saves the World, you'll like this (IMO this is better than Cthulhu - the art is nicer and you can actually follow the maps).  Try the demo, it's a good representation of the game play.

reviewText: I received a free download key for this in exchange for leaving a review as I purchased the game from the website directly.  It is a fantastic game, I've already played it through once and I am currently working on the 2nd time around and have already found stuff I missed 1st time.  A lovely little RPG with a sense of humour and various quirky characters, the ending changes according to choices made during the game so playable again and again.  Have purchased the entire Aveyond series of games over the years and love all of them, I would find it difficult to choose a favourite.

reviewText: So this is SoloKane's wife writing a review for Aveyond....in case anyone was wondering why he was playing this game.  Definitely not his style but totally mine.  I have been a huge fan of the Aveyond series for years.  I actually purchased this directly from the game maker and then got a free steam key from them for writing a review.  To date I have over 20 hours of game play and it's so much fun.  The characters are interesting and funny.  Puzzles are challenging.  This is a great game in the Aveyond series with updates in its gaming system.  Anyone who likes RPG that has a sarcastic fun sense of humor is going to love this game and the whole series.  Super pleased that it's not by chapters like the last game.  Thanks Aveyond Kingdom!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
One of the best games I have ever played and even though it says I don't have much playtime I bought it on on the official site for twenty dollars and it was worth every penny. I highly recommend you all try this but here are my thoughts on the game.
Pros:
-Beautiful artwork, You will be able to tell a how much work was put into every area.
-Humor: Its not often when you find a good game full of humor and I actaully laughed out loud twice
-Story: Very good story, not the best in the world but definitly a reason to buy the game
-Great community: The devs are involved and always ready to help and so are the people i have met who play the game
-Good playtime and replay value: You will get plenty of playtime I believe i have a little more than 30 hours on just one playthrough (I am a bit slow) and I intend to do another playthrough
-Combat: While the combat system isn't the most uniqe I just LOVE how all the different characters have there own uniqe abilities and systems for those abilities. Its not just the boring use mana to cast a spell, or have a basic attack
-Puzzles: There were some puzzles that I really enjoyed to solve, my favorite part of the game was the probably the dungeon which is a very confusing hour puzzle, that I loved to solve.
There are more benefits that I loved but those are probably the main ones
Cons:
-Navigating the map: It takes a while getting used to navigating the world map and it can be a fair amount of walking getting to where you want to go sometimes
-Vauge quest descriptions sometimes: Sometimes a quest can be kind of vauge and its hard to figure out where your supposed to go or do.

All in all I definitely reccomend this game.

reviewText:
THIS MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!!!

For my review, I'd give it 4/5 (but totally recommand it!). Mainly because I kinda didn't like the art. It really could have been better.

The music on the other hand was (and I quote Sid!) grandiose! Music (for me) is the most important thing in a video game lacking voice over. aveyond 4 blew my mind with its music. My favorite tracks were the ones playing in Ulrock, Delamere and Halaina.

The story was really fun; I enjoyed every bit of it. And I loved how every party member had their own little endings and the consequences of the sidequest we played too!

My favorites were Myst and Hi'beru. Really loved it when Myst angered Boyle. And how Hi'beru always came to rescue when dreams were involved.. and that ending with the gladiator? Priceless!!!

I had Ingrid paired with Phye in my game just because I didn't like her with Boyle. Call me silly, but I think he and Myst have much more chemistry :P

Besides, Ingrid deserves a strong man and Phye was prefect.

Hinting that Boyle has some connections with the Pendragons was interested. I'd love to see this idea being expand on in the future. It really sets the bases for a new game *wink wink*

reviewText:
I have been a long-time fan of all the Aveyond games--they've followed me through childhood--and playing Aveyond 4 as an adult has been a great way to come back to the series. Each of the games is their own experience, and while in certain narrative ways Aveyond 4 feels like a regression, as far as gameplay goes, the series has grown in some fantastic ways. Though I feel as though the protagonist was the wrong choice for this game, the game maps are extensive and rewarding, and the arc of the game is smooth and fulfilling. The way the game plays is excellent, and the narrative aspect mostly provides context for how to view it, so although I was largely disappointed in the story of the game, I loved Aveyond 4 as a whole.

Overall, I had a great experience and would wholly recommend it. That said, this review is largely narrative critique.

THE NARRATIVE:

Narratively, Boyle felt like the wrong choice for the protagonist. He is not engaging as a main character--the humor regarding 'retired villains' and 'heroes' fell flat, and it felt reductive. The best part about him was his relationship with his dog, but that dedication is not enough to make a protagonist. An attempt at humor regarding evildoing in a comical tone is not enough to make a protagonist, either. While the backstory about how he found his dog as a pup was touching, it does not offer strong enough motive for him to be the main character of this story. He is mostly a static character. While he does admit that doing good is pretty good, it is dulled by the joke of it all, and the retired supervillain aspect diminishes the entire relationship of good and evil. Basically, it seems as though he was truly good all along, and the only amount of growth is in his awareness of this, and it is not enough to drive an entire game. His personal stake in this journey is not, narratively, the strongest one.

Boyle is looking for his dog; Myst is looking for her brother. In order to find his dog, Boyle must find Myst's brother, who was snatched by a demon. Even the game's title, Shadow Of The Mist"
date: suggests that Myst is the one with more to lose
recommended: here. Boyle plays the reluctant hero
hoursPlayed: but it is irritating to have what feels so much like Myst's story filtered through this flat
voteText: reductive joke of a retired supervillain. Myst has never been away from the mountain
helpfulPercent: and while she also needs to find her little brother
votesHelpful: she longs to see the sights outside of The Mist. She has so much to learn
votesTotal: so far to go. She has the most reason to go on this journey to defeat the demon and save her brother
votesFunny: and she has the farthest to grow. She is the most dynamic character
commentsCount: at a tipping point of her life.\n\nIf Myst were the main character
column16: the framing of this game would've been much more powerful--and it would've offered a kind of serious beauty to it
column19: which was personally an extremely successful
column20: gorgeous game with a very gentle
column21: fairy-tale like story. This still would've been light-hearted in (many ways
column23: but it would've also had the background context of a fairy-tale. This game could've so easily been absolutely incredible
column25: had Myst been the protagonist. She has every reason to be. Also
column26: her background as a Myst Wraith is so much more compelling than the dull
column27:
simplifying joke of the Retired Supervillain.

THE GAMEPLAY:

The maps are beautiful. They are detailed
column29: and so very rewarding. The chests are set up so that they can be seen when strolling on the most obvious paths
column30: and while it does take some challenge to look for them
column31: it is not to the point of frustration. Taking the effort to go the long way around for a chest that was seen ten minutes earlier is always worth the effort. The color schemes of the maps are brilliant
column33: and the layouts of all the buildings are varied
column35: not tired and reused. Each part of the journey has its own distinctive map which feels like its own little area within a larger world
column36: which helps create a better idea of this lush
column37: full world of Aveyond. The only complaint here is that some of the maps are so ambitious that they lag on soe systems. I also loved how purposeful all the sidequests were; everything was important.\n\nThe battle system is set up in a spin of the traditional turn-based system. It makes battles so much less tedious. Each character has a different role in battle
column38: with their own pros and cons
column39: and it is very fun to think about how best to use each character. Myst has a few different abilities
column40: including a healing and shapeshifting one
column41: and using these abilities does not require a cost of mana or skill point
column42: although it does mean that these abilities aren't as powerful as ones that would have a cost. Boyle's darkness points are replenished with physical attacks
column43: and he uses these same points to cast magic
column44: and it is very fun to have a wizard type who is also a formidable physical attacker--in addition to his minion
column45: whose attacks add additional damage at every turn. Those are only two of the characters
column46: but all of them have roles that aren't so simple as deducting a mana / skill point cost. The character battle roles are fun
column47: and the battles demand a measure of attention that makes it so they aren't a matter of grinding through the same predictable battle rhythm again and again. It's more fluid than that.\n\nThe only thing I would say is that there are many characters who get introduced too late in the game to really develop an affection for them
column48: or a feel for their role in battle
column49: so they don't get the opportunity to shine. It's more difficult to care about them
column50:
when there is so little time to get familiar with them.

LASTLY:

In a lot of ways
column51: I do not think Aveyond is the right arena to even attempt deconstructing Heroes or Villains--that seems more the space of cape comics and games inspired by those. It felt odd and uncomfortable to reference that type of Hero vs. Villain relationship in a largely original
column52: fantastical world such as Aveyond. Also uncomfortable in the game was the way sprites from popular anime series appeared in prominent side quest characters
column54: no one would notice Hetalia sprites or Chi from Chobits acting in ways that seemed to serve no purpose
column56: to their original series at all. It was not right to include representations of those licensed designs in this original game being sold for its own profit. Original sprites should have been made by the Aveyond team. Both of these aspects broke immersion of Aveyond as the world of Aveyond
column59: its own mythos which does at times reference outside ones
column60: like Aveyond 2 and the Snow Queen
column61: and moments like referencing the Fruit of the (Greek) Gods (a pomegranate) in Aveyond 1.\n\nIn terms of media representation
column62: the Aveyond series made such an impact on me as a kid realizing that girls and women were powerful
column64: and to see them in positions of power
column65: as heroes unqualified by the acts of men
column67: if I wanted to play a game about a man
column68: I'd look literally anywhere else. That was one of the first reasons why Boyle failed as a protagonist for me. He has nothing to add to the conversation. He is not refreshing in any way. There are countless characters like him
column69: and there are so few respectful representations of women in games
column70: especially Fantasy ones known for their trope of women as reward for the (male) hero's triumphs
column72: or as vile and petty temptations of evil.\n\nAll this said: I loved this game. It may be because I played it most recently
column73: but it was my favorite game to play. But
column75: it doesn't compare with Aveyond 1 or Aveyond 2 and the way those games stayed in my heart. I still had a blast
column77: and am looking forward to replaying it\n\n*Disclaimer: I received a free Steam key for this review
column78: and I originally got the game elsewhere."

reviewText: I love this  game. I have all of the Aveyond games and they just keep getting better and better.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is my favorite Aveyond game to date, and I've enjoyed all of them! It has an awesome cast and story. I love that the main character is a failed villain - it's a nice change from farmboy-turned-hero saves the day RPGs, and it makes for some very funny writing. The puzzles are unique and really, really well done. Battle is intuitive without being tedious, and the different skills characters can learn are fun to experiment with!\n\nI bought Shadow of the Mist through the Aveyond website, and I've played it through twice so far. I received this Steam key for free in return for writing a review. I don't use Steam often, but I've already told everyone I know to play Aveyond, so why not? :)
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I like the game. It is the 4th in a series set in the same universe. All games are independent from each other and can be played independently.
Aveyond 4: Shadow Of The Mist is a classic RPG game that follows a story line, but allows to create your own fighting team from a group of characters that can join you. It involves monster fighting and puzzle solving.
The graphics are old school.
The story line traditional, but the dialogue funny and tongue in cheek.
The game has 3 difficulty setting. Multiple save slots make it easy to work on alternate story arcs for some of the team members and changing the finale.
I enjoyed playing Aveyond 4.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This game is an absolute masterpiece! It allows for players who have anywhere from no time on their hands to three months. You can have fun playing this game no matter how much or how little you can devote to it. The storyline is entertaining, the characters are great fun, the minions are delightful, the side quests are enchanting, and the mini-games are cute. The characters themselves are actually diverse enough in their abilities to make your party selection an actual act of strategy whereas it used to be mostly a question of which magic weilder/fighter balance do you prefer; now you have to decide whether you want healing, fire, magic, multi-attacks, dream magic, or assorted team-attacks. The combat system is a vast improvement on any I have heretofore played. In short: BUY THIS GAME!

Boyle is looking for his dog; Myst is looking for her brother. In order to find his dog, Boyle must find Myst's brother, who was snatched by a demon. Even the game's title, Shadow Of The Mist"

reviewText:
Hello,

first I must say that I've completed the game four times already, because I bought it on the official web when it came out and got a free steam key as a present, so this is the 5th time I play it. I've been following Amaranth Games since Aveyond 1 and I'm a huge fan of Aveyond series and JRPG in general.

I highly recommend this game, because first of all it is really enjoyable and fun to play, you don't get bored while playing and that is very important for me as a player. It contains so many funny situations and exellent humour, characters that are not your everyday cliché heroes, beatiful maps and places to visit, and don't get me start about those amazing puzzles and dungeons. I mean you really need to try the Halaina Dungeon, it's one of my fav things in the game. You also can do many other things like: joining a coven, marry your characters, join the night watch...yes there is a night watch and quests that you need to complete at night, collect some cute things, pumpkin smashing etc. You can choose between 3 covens and 3 characters, and 3 difficulty modes to play, so the game has a replay value as well. So give this game a chance, trust me, you won't regret it :)

Kudos to Amaranth Games team for making another beautiful and highly enjoyable game :)


Moony

reviewText:
The heroes found your evil lair, made it past traps, minions, even a dragon, and now you are utterly defeated.  So what's a villain to do?  Retire.  That is until your dog goes missing after a mysterious fog settles over town.  And now you must go back out into the world to rescue him.

And so the game begins.  Full of wit, well designed gameplay and surprising endearing ex-villains, Aveyond 4 has lived up to all my expectations.  I especially love that this is a full length game, not somethng that is over in the first few hours.  After 17+ hours of game time I'm still discovering new areas of the map, unlocking new side quests, and making progress on the main storyline.  There's still plenty of game ahead and I'm excited to see where it goes.

I originally purchased this game on the Aveyond website when it was first released.  I have been a fan of Amaranth Games since Aveyond 1 and I'm thrilled to see this latest installment with its twist on the classic hero's journey.  I received a free key to download the game here on Steam so that I could share my impressions of the game with the Steam community.  I fully recommend Aveyond 4 to anyone who likes good humor and great RPGs.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As a long time fan of the Aveyond series, I was excited to hear Aveyond 4 finally come out, and purchased it the day of release.  Soon, I got a free key for Steam from the developer and am excited to see this title finally out on Steam!  I completed the game in a blind playthrough in about 26 1/2 hours between Steam and the non-steam installer.

This game has all of the humor of the other games in the series, but has the unique twist of featuring a villain as the protagonist!  Some of the ongoing storylines from previous games find their way into this one as various cameos, which will appeal to fans of the series.

As for the game itself, it's a fairly easy to pick up RPG.  Instead of the archetypical classes you find in other fantasy based games, each character has their own set of skills and abilities, and each character obtains their abilities in different ways.

The story is engaging, and even the side quests are interesting and entertaining.  My only complaint is that the difficulty of the monsters in the last zone of the game is FAR above the difficulty found in the rest of the game... for instance, the monsters in the previous zone would hit my characters for 1, but in the final zone could kill with bad RNG.

Aside from that nitpick, the game feels polished and plays well on an XBox One controller, despite having to use an analog stick instead of a D-pad.  My only suggestions for improvement are the lack of a scaling full screen mode, and the ability to remap controls.

If you like engaging, story-driven RPGs, Aveyond 4 - or any Aveyond game, really - is for you.

reviewText: So this is SoloKane's wife writing a review for Aveyond....in case anyone was wondering why he was playing this game.  Definitely not his style but totally mine.  I have been a huge fan of the Aveyond series for years.  I actually purchased this directly from the game maker and then got a free steam key from them for writing a review.  To date I have over 20 hours of game play and it's so much fun.  The characters are interesting and funny.  Puzzles are challenging.  This is a great game in the Aveyond series with updates in its gaming system.  Anyone who likes RPG that has a sarcastic fun sense of humor is going to love this game and the whole series.  Super pleased that it's not by chapters like the last game.  Thanks Aveyond Kingdom!

reviewText:
One of the best games I have ever played and even though it says I don't have much playtime I bought it on on the official site for twenty dollars and it was worth every penny. I highly recommend you all try this but here are my thoughts on the game.
Pros:
-Beautiful artwork, You will be able to tell a how much work was put into every area.
-Humor: Its not often when you find a good game full of humor and I actaully laughed out loud twice
-Story: Very good story, not the best in the world but definitly a reason to buy the game
-Great community: The devs are involved and always ready to help and so are the people i have met who play the game
-Good playtime and replay value: You will get plenty of playtime I believe i have a little more than 30 hours on just one playthrough (I am a bit slow) and I intend to do another playthrough
-Combat: While the combat system isn't the most uniqe I just LOVE how all the different characters have there own uniqe abilities and systems for those abilities. Its not just the boring use mana to cast a spell, or have a basic attack
-Puzzles: There were some puzzles that I really enjoyed to solve, my favorite part of the game was the probably the dungeon which is a very confusing hour puzzle, that I loved to solve.
There are more benefits that I loved but those are probably the main ones
Cons:
-Navigating the map: It takes a while getting used to navigating the world map and it can be a fair amount of walking getting to where you want to go sometimes
-Vauge quest descriptions sometimes: Sometimes a quest can be kind of vauge and its hard to figure out where your supposed to go or do.

All in all I definitely reccomend this game.

reviewText:
20 hours in and I've finished my first playthrough.  I loved this game!  I'm a big fan of the whole Aveyond series.  This one ties in nicely to the other games, but you can definitely play it without having played the others - there's just little bonus jokes and such that you only get if you've played all the games.  The dialog is funny, clever, cute and well-written.  All the grammar and spelling is correct (one of my pet peeves is games with incorrect grammar and spelling, the Aveyond ones are safe from that).
This is an RPG Maker game with very cute sprites.  The sprites are very nice, and you can actually tell which sprite is which character.  The art (the non-RPG maker generated art) is lovely; the character art in particular was great, with very expressive faces (that actually looked like realistic emotions instead of something out of a Looney Toon).

I recommend this to anyone with a good sense of humor, and anyone who likes RPGs.  If you liked the other Aveyond games, you'll almost certainly enjoy this.  If you liked Cthulhu Saves the World, you'll like this (IMO this is better than Cthulhu - the art is nicer and you can actually follow the maps).  Try the demo, it's a good representation of the game play.
